choices.text: Capsule covering the testis contain three layers; tunica albuginea, tunica vaginalis, tunica adventitia
The mediastinum contain blood and lymph vessels
The maturation of germ cells covers a period of about 10-12 days
The average weight of each testis is 100 g in a normal adult

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about the normal testis from the following.
questions.solution:
THE NORMAL ADULT TESTIS

  • Paired organ that lies within the scrotum
  • Suspended by the spermatic cord.
  • The average weight of each testis is 15-19 g (choice D), the right usually being 10% heavier than the left.
  • The organ is covered by a capsule composed of three layers: (choice A)
    • The outer serosa or tunica vaginalis(covered by a flattened layer of mesothelial cells)
    • The tunica albuginea
    • The inner tunica vasculosa.
  • The posterior portion of the capsule, called the mediastinum, contains blood and lymph vessels, nerves, and the mediastinal portion of the rete testis.
  • The parenchyma is divided into approximately 250 lobules, each lobule containing up to four seminiferous tubules.
  • The seminiferous tubules are bound by a limiting membrane (made up of basal lamina and alternating layers of myoid cells and collagen fibers)
    • Contain germ cells(in various stages of development)
    • Sertoli cells
  • The maturation of germ cells in man covers a period of about 70 days.
  • The interstitium contains
    • stromal elements Leydig cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common blood borne metastatic site of testicular germ cell tumors?
questions.solution:
LOCAL SPREAD OF TESTICULAR GERM CELL TUMORS:

  • Spread to tunica albuginea, but invasion of the testicular hilum is actually a much more common.

LYMPH-BORNE METASTASES:

  • spread first to periaortic and iliac lymph nodes and later to mediastinal and left supraclavicular nodes.
  • Retroperitoneal metastases are highly placed, immediately below the renal vessels. (On the side of the tumor in about 80%-86% and bilateral in about 13%-20%)
  • The presence of contralateral metastases in the absence of ipsilateral metastases is rare.
  • Involvement of inguinal lymph nodes does not occur unless there is invasion of the skin of the scrotum

BLOOD-BORNE METASTASES:

  • Most frequently in lungs, liver, brain, and bone.
  • Choriocarcinoma
    • high incidence of brain metastases
    • widespread metastases by the time the tumor is diagnosed
  • bone metastases in seminoma.
  • Embryonal carcinoma frequently metastasizes early

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Common Sites of Metastasis of testis germ cell tumors:

  • Lymphatic Spread:
    • Retroperitoneal lymph nodes: Primary site of metastasis due to drainage via testicular lymphatics to para-aortic nodes.
    • Supraclavicular lymph nodes: Advanced disease.
  • Hematogenous Spread:
    • Lungs: Most common visceral site.
    • Liver: In advanced cases.
    • Brain: In aggressive or late-stage tumors.
    • Bone: Rare but can occur.

questions.text: A 56 years old man comes to the general surgeon with complaints of painless mass in his right testis and bilateral breast enlargement. Microscopic image is given below of this mass. Immunohistochemical stain is positive for inhibin and ki67. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is Leydig cell tumor

  • Increased production of androgens and/or estrogens.
  • Most occur in adults
  • Most common Symptoms:
    • Palpable testicular mass
    • Gynecomastia
  • The few that occur in childhood cause precocious pseudopuberty with growth of pubic hair and penis, but without spermatocytic maturation in the non-neoplastic testis(hence the prefix pseudo); these symptoms usually regress after removal of the tumor
  • Grossly- Small (average size, 3 cm), sharply delimited solid nodule embedded within the testicle The brown color it usually exhibits is one of its most distinguishing gross features.
  • Microscopically
    • well-defined outlines
    • deeply acidophilic but occasionally clear cytoplasm, and a
    • round or oval (occasionally grooved) nucleus.
    • Lipochrome pigment and Reinke crystalloids are sometimes present.
    • The pattern of growth is generally solid, but trabecular, myxoid, pseudofollicular, and microcystic formations can be present.
    • Immunohistochemical markers: Inhibin, calretinin, SF-1, CD99, and Mart-1
    • About5% of leydig cell tumor show evidence of malignant behavior in the form of metastatic disease, particularly to lymph nodes, lung, and liver.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Malignant Leydig cell tumors:

  • Occur exclusively in adults
  • Endocrine changes
  • Larger than the benign variety (average size, 7.5 cm), are more
  • Infiltrative
  • Exhibit necrosis, blood vessel invasion, nuclear atypia, numerous mitoses (>3 mitoses per 10 high-power fields), and lack of lipochrome pigment.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leydig_cell_tumour

questions.text: A 38 years old male had undergone left orchidectomy with mass present on the epididymis. The gross and microscopic images shows the following feature. The immunohistochemical markers like pankeratin and calretinin are positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Adenomatoid tumor

  • Benign mesothelial tumor
  • The most common neoplasm of the epididymis
  • The third or fourth decade of life
  • Also occurs in the testicular spermatic cordand ejaculatory duct in males and in the fallopian tube and uterus in females.
  • It presents clinically as a Mass, sometimes associated with pain.
  • Grossly, small(average size, 2 cm), solid, firm, gray-white nodule and occasionally containing small cysts. (Shown in the image)
  • Microscopically-
    • Unencapsulated and poorly circumscribed
    • Cells- cuboidal to flattened
    • Pattern- solid cords with an epithelial appearance alternating with channels having dilated lumina simulating vascular structures.
    • prominent cytoplasmic vacuolization.
    • Tubular areas often have an atrophic lining and distinctive thread-like strands crossing the luminal space are common.
  • Immunocytochemically, there is strong reactivity for pankeratin, calretinin, D2-40, and WT1, while negative for CEA

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Adenomatoid tumor is a benign mesothelial tumor commonly found in the genital tract, particularly the epididymis, testicular tunics, and occasionally the testis.

Gross Appearance:

  • Well-circumscribed, small (<2 cm), firm, white or yellow nodular lesion.
  • Located in the epididymis or tunica albuginea.

Microscopic Features:

  • Tubular or gland-like spaces lined by flattened or cuboidal cells.
  • Abundant fibrous stroma.
  • Cells often have eosinophilic cytoplasm and bland nuclei.

choices.text: Prostatic carcinoma originate most common in the transition zone
Prostate in a normal adult man weighs 20 g approximately
Glands lined by 2 layers of cells basal layer and columnar cells

questions.solution:
The prostate:

  • Retroperitoneal organ encircling the neck of the bladder and urethra
  • Lacks a distinct capsule. (Choice C)
  • In a normal adult, the prostate weighs approximately 20 g (choice B)
  • Divided into four biologically and anatomically distinct regions, the peripheral, central, transition, and periurethral zones.
  • Most hyperplasias arise in the transition zone
  • Most carcinomas originate in the peripheral zone (choice A)
  • Histologically, the prostate consists of glands separated by abundant fibromuscular stroma.
  • The glands are lined by two layers of cells: (choice D)
    • A basal layer of low cuboidal basal epithelium covered by a layer of columnar secretory cells which often contain small papillary infoldings.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Zones:

  • Peripheral Zone: Most common site for carcinoma.
  • Central Zone: Surrounds ejaculatory ducts.
  • Transition Zone: Common site for Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).
  • Anterior Fibromuscular Zone: Non-glandular.

questions.text: Which of the following condition can cause male infertility?
questions.solution:
HYDROCELE: (choice C)

  • The tunica vaginalis (mesothelial-lined surface exterior to the testis) may accumulate serous fluid causing enlargement of the scrotal sac.
  • By transillumination: clear, translucent character of the contained fluid.
  • Rarely, malignant mesotheliomas and ovarian epithelial-type tumors can arise from the tunica vaginalis.

HEMATOCELE: (choice B)

  • Collection of blood in the tunica vaginalis
  • After testicular trauma or torsion, or in individuals with systemic bleeding disorders.

CHYLOCELE:

  • Accumulation of lymph in the tunica
  • Always found in patients with elephantiasis who have widespread, severe lymphatic obstruction caused, for example, by filariasis

SPERMATOCELE: (choice B)

  • A small cystic accumulation of semen in dilated efferent ducts or ducts of the rete testis.

VARICOCELE: (choice D)

  • Dilated vein in the spermatic cord
  • Asymptomatic
  • Contributing factor to infertility
  • Corrected by surgical repair

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Varicocele is the abnormal dilation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum due to defective venous drainage.

Reference: https://www.spectrumhealthlakeland.org/lakeland-ear-nose-and-throat/ent-health-library/Content/3/88227/

Reference: https://www.institutobernabeu.com/en/blog/varicocele-and-infertility/

choices.text: Pelvis is the first to get involved
Hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia are present along with bony metastasis
Clusters of malignant glands surrounded by exuberant new bone formation

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about bony metastasis of prostatic adenocarcinoma from the following.
questions.solution:
Prostatic adenocarcinoma

  • The most common sites of metastatic spread of prostatic carcinoma are the skeletal system and lymph nodes.

BONE METASTASESIN PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA:

  • Multiple but can be solitary
  • Characteristically osteoblastic(choice B), but can also be mixed or entirely osteolytic.
  • Descending order of frequency - hematogenous spread to bones
    • Lumbar spine (choice A) > proximal femur > pelvis > thoracic spine > ribs
  • Microscopically, clusters of malignant glands are seen surrounded by exuberant new bone formation.(Choice D) When the bone metastases
  • Extensive bone metastases:
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hypophosphatemia
    • Increased serum alkaline phosphatase levels
  • Immunohistochemical Reactions for PSAP, PSA, and NKX3.1 are usually positive, even after decalcification.

Other sites of bony metastases: LUNG, BREAST, LIVER, ADRENAL GLAND, CNS, EYE AND SKIN.

  • Lung metastasis:
    • lymphangitic pattern of spread
    • Massive pleural effusion may be the initial symptom
    • The pattern of growth may be microacinar, tubulopapillary, or carcinoid-like.
  • Breast metastasis:
    • sometimes bilaterally, particularly in patients taking estrogens.
    • clinically: presents with gynecomastia and
    • microscopically with primary breast carcinoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common sites of metastatic spread of prostatic carcinoma are the skeletal system and lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic alterations is seen in the prostate?
questions.solution:
The most common genetic alteration in the prostate is a chromosomal rearrangement, which occur in approximately half of prostate cancers, place the involved ETS oncogene under the control of the androgen-regulated TMPRSS2 promoter and lead to its overexpression in an androgen-dependent fashion.

  • Silencing of the gene encoding p27, an inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases, is another common event. (Choice C)
  • Amplification of MYC and deletion of PTEN, both of which accelerate cell growth and may contribute to resistance to antiandrogen therapy.
  • In late-stage disease:
    • Loss of TP53(by deletion or mutation)
    • Deletions of RB
    • Amplifications of the AR gene

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common genetic alteration in the prostate is a chromosomal rearrangement, which occur in approximately half of prostate cancers, place the involved ETS oncogene under the control of the androgen-regulated TMPRSS2 promoter and lead to its overexpression in an androgen-dependent fashion.

choices.text: Atherosclerotic narrowing of blood supply in old age

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of testicular atrophy?
questions.solution:
Testicular atrophy causes:

  1. Progressive atherosclerotic narrowing Of the blood supply in old age;
  2. end-stage inflammatory orchitis
  3. Cryptorchidism
  4. Hypopituitarism
  5. Generalized malnutrition or cachexia
  6. Irradiation
  7. Prolonged administration of antiandrogens (e.g., for treatment of carcinoma of the prostate)
  8. Cirrhosis
  9. Primary failure of genetic origin, such as in Klinefelter syndrome; and
  10. Exhaustion atrophy, which may follow persistent stimulation by high levels of follicle-stimulating pituitary hormone.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hyperpituitarism is not a cause of testicular atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following patient populations is typically affected by gonadoblastoma?
questions.solution:
PHENOTYPIC FEMALE, GENOTYPIC MALE

GONADOBLASTOMA:

  • Primarily affects phenotypic females
  • The y chromosome is typically present ( Choice a).
  • Remaining cases are comprised of phenotypic and genotypic males (choice d ).
  • Combination of GERM CELLS and SEX CORD-STROMAL CELLS is gonadoblastoma
  • This tumor occurs practically always in sexually abnormal individuals, most commonly affected by gonadal dysgenesis and carrying all or part of the Y chromosome (i.e. XY gonadal dysgenesis and XO-XY mosaicism but not XX gonadal dysgenesis).
  • The risk of neoplasia in these dysgenetic gonads - 25%.
  • They have also been seen in association with ataxia-telangiectasia and as a cryptorchid testis.
  • Approximately 36% of the tumors are bilateral.
  • The key microscopic feature is the admixture of PRIMITIVE GERM CELLS (RESEMBLING THOSE OF DYSGERMINOMA) WITH SEX CORD-STROMAL CELLS resembling morphologically and immunohistochemically immature Sertoli and granulosa cells.
  • Steroid hormone-producing cells may also be present, especially after puberty.
  • The germ cell component of gonadoblastoma may overgrow the stromal elements and result in the formation of a germinoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A rare, mixed gonadal tumor composed of germ cells and sex cord-stromal elements, often arising in dysgenetic gonads.

  • Occurs primarily in individuals with disorders of sex development (DSD), such as Turner syndrome or androgen insensitivity syndrome.
  • Typically seen in phenotypic females or males with ambiguous genitalia.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical and laboratory findings are NOT characteristic of the lesion depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
The lesion depicted in this image is an example of CLASSICAL SEMINOMA.

  • Seminoma : 2 types
  • Microscopically:
    • Uniform and relatively evenly spaced tumor cells
    • Abundant clear cytoplasm
    • Sharply outlined cell membranes
    • Large centrally located nuclei with
    • Finely granular chromatin and flattened edges
    • Central nucleoli are often prominent and may be multiple
    • Variable number of mitoses
    • Sometimes plasmacytoid appearance,
    • The tumor cells are typically arranged in NESTSoutlined by fibrous bands; these bands are infiltrated by lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes.
    • Other morphologic patterns: cord-like (single file), tubular, trabecular, microcystic, intertubular, and signet ring-like vacuoles.
    • Elevated serum AFP is atypical and suggests a yolk sac component ( choice B).
    • Elevated hCG, on the other hand, is not unusual due to the variable background syncytiotrophoblasts which may be present and should not be misinterpreted as a choriocarcinoma component (choice C).
    • Hypercalcemia(choice A) and exophthalmos (choice D) may be present secondary to a paraendocrine abnormality and paraneoplastic syndrome, respectively.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Microscopic Features:

  • Tumor Cells:
    • Large, round to polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm (rich in glycogen).
    • Central, prominent nuclei with a nucleolus ("fried egg" appearance).
    • Cells are arranged in sheets or nests separated by fibrous septa.
  • Fibrous Septa:
    • Thin, delicate bands of fibrous tissue infiltrated by lymphocytes(T-cell predominant).
    • Granulomatous reaction may be present in some cases.
  • Stroma:
    • Sparse, with a prominent lymphocytic infiltrate.
    • Occasional plasma cells or histiocytes.

Immunohistochemistry (IHC):

  • Positive Markers:
    • Placental Alkaline Phosphatase (PLAP): Strong cytoplasmic staining.
    • OCT3/4 and SALL4: Nuclear positivity.
    • c-KIT (CD117): Membranous staining.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common secondary malignant neoplasm arising in association with this lesion?
questions.solution:
SOMATIC-TYPE MALIGNANCIES IN GERM CELL TUMORS.

  • Testicular germ cell tumors develop malignancies-referred to as somatic type-having appearances analogous to those of conventional tumors of nongerm-cell nature.
  • The malignant component is often
    • In the form of sarcoma (such as RHABDOMYOSARCOMA) or
    • Neuroepithelial type neoplasms similar to those in the central nervous system (PRIMITIVE NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR)
    • in the form of epithelial malignancy (such as ADENOCARCINOMA).
  • This phenomenon is designated as somatic type malignancy; older terms such as "teratoma with malignant transformation" are not recommended.
    • The most common secondary malignant neoplasm arising in association with testicular teratoma is rhabdomyosarcoma of either embryonal or alveolar type (choice A). Unlike in its ovarian counterpart, carcinomas arising from mature epithelium are much more rare.
    • Leiomyosarcoma and chondrosarcoma are not commonly described. choices C&D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Testicular germ cell tumors develop malignancies-referred to as somatic type-having appearances analogous to those of conventional tumors of nongerm-cell nature

questions.text: An orchidectomy specimen of 44 years old man with left testicular mass and gynecomastia shows the following morphological features. Immunohistochemical markers showed immunoreactivity for Pan-Cytokeratin, SF-1, CD99, Beta catenin and negative for PLAP, CD117. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sertoli cell tumors (not otherwise specified [NOS])

  • Arise in the descended testis of normal individuals
  • Associated with gynecomastia
  • Gross: well circumscribed mass, white or yellow, and firm, with focal cystic areas.
  • Microscopically:
    • Cord-like or tubular formations lined by elongated cells having the appearance of Sertoli cells.
    • The cytoplasm is moderate to abundant, with a pale to intense eosinophilic quality. Lipid vacuoles are present in some cases.
  • Immunohistochemically, positive for keratin, SF-1, CD99, calretinin, melan A, and WT1 but are negative for PLAP and CD117 (c-KIT)
  • Inhibin is positive in only 50% of tumors, while Nuclear β-catenin is expressed in 60%-70%.
  • About one-tenth of Sertoli cell tumors behave in a malignant fashion, the most common site of metastatic involvement: the iliac and para-aortic lymph nodes.
  • The treatment of Sertoli cell tumor is orchiectomy.

Gynecomastia is not seen in cases of seminoma and post pubertal teratoma. (Choice C&D)

Seminoma shows immunoreactivity for PLAP & CD117. (ChoiceC)

Leydig cell tumor shows gynecomastia but again morphology is not matching with the given image. (Choice A)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumour typically found in the testis. It is occasionally seen in women.

Reference: https://librepathology.org/wiki/Sertoli_cell_tumour
